intro: Anethum cymbocarpum, commonly known as the Indian cumin or wild cumin, is a herbaceous annual plant native to the Mediterranean region and parts of Asia. It grows to a height of about 30–60 cm and features slender, branched stems covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in umbels, followed by distinctive, three-lobed, oval-shaped fruits that are typically used as a spice. Its leaves are finely divided and aromatic, contributing to its culinary and medicinal uses. Anethum cymbocarpum is well adapted to dry, sunny conditions and thrives in well-drained soils.
